Individual lesions are firm, pruritic, pink to skin-colored umbilicated papules (shown below). A curd-like material can be expressed from the central umbilication

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Herpes virus: Herpes simplex virus (HSV) infections typically present with grouped vesicles on an erythematous base, which then progress to pustules, ulcers, and crusts. The histology usually shows multinucleated giant cells with intranuclear inclusions on a Tzanck smear, not the intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies seen in this case.

 

Option B. Verruca vulgaris: Also known as common warts, verruca vulgaris is caused by the human papillomavirus (HPV). These lesions are typically hyperkeratotic, exophytic papules with a rough surface. Histologically, they show papillomatosis, hyperkeratosis, and koilocytosis (vacuolated cells with a halo around the nucleus). These features are distinct from the molluscum bodies seen in Molluscum contagiosum.

 

Option D. Lichen planus: Lichen planus is an inflammatory condition that presents with pruritic, polygonal, flat-topped, violaceous papules, often with Wickham striae (fine white lines) on the surface. Histologically, it shows a band-like lymphocytic infiltrate at the dermoepidermal junction, hypergranulosis, and saw-toothing of the rete ridges. These findings are not consistent with the histological image provided, which shows molluscum bodies.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Molluscum contagiosum is characterized by the presence of intracytoplasmic molluscum bodies (Henderson-Patterson bodies) within keratinocytes, and it presents clinically as skin-colored, umbilicated papules.

 

Ref: Robbins and Cotran pathologic basis of disease, 8th edition, Pg 1940

choices.text: Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations

questions.text: What are the potential observations that could be observed in this patient? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Loss of sensation over foot

 

In this case, the patient is likely to have a neuropathic/trophic ulcer, which is characterized by a lack of sensation over the foot due to peripheral neuropathy. These ulcers are painless and have punched-out margins with the presence of calluses. The ulcer is located on the plantar surface of the foot (weight bearing area). The other options, such as decreased pulsations in the posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis arteries, positive Trendelenburg sign, and pain on compression of calf, are not likely to be seen in this patient with a neuropathic ulcer.

 

Loss of sensation over the foot can lead to neuropathic/trophic ulcers as seen above. This is usually seen in neuropathies like Diabetes.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Decreased posterior tibial & dorsalis pedis pulsations: Decreased or absent posterior tibial and dorsalis pedis pulsations are indicative of vascular compromise or reduced blood flow to the lower extremity. This can lead to ischemic ulcers which are seen at tips of toes, web spaces, dorsum of foot etc. The image does not suggest an ischemic ulcer.

 

Option C. Positive Trendelenberg test: This is seen in varicose veins with saphenofemoral incompetence, and may have varicose ulcers above medial malleolus (Gaiter’s area). The image is not a case of varicose ulcer.

 

Option D. Pain on compression of calf: Pain on compression of the calf may indicate a potential deep vein thrombosis (DVT), which can lead to calf pain and swelling and venous ulcers. The image is not a case of DVT with venous ulcer.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Loss of sensation over the foot is a potential observation that could be observed in a patient with neuropathic/trophic ulcers.

questions.text: Following is a graphic representation of a patient admitted in medicine ward with fever. What could be the possible diagnosis? (AIIMS MAY 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Leptospirosis

 

Image shows typical biphasic illness with initial leptospiremic phase followed by immune phase.

 

Other illness that shows biphasic pattern include measles, Tick borne encephalitis virus, rarely Zika virus.

 

Modified Faine Criteria is used for diagnosis.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Monophasic illness with predominant CNS and multisystem involvement.

 

Option C. Undulant fever presenting with PUO, muscle pain, thoracic backpain

 

Option D. Enteric fever causes step ladder pattern of fever.

 

 

Educational Objective:
 

Leptospirosis should be considered in patients presenting with a biphasic fever pattern, especially when supported by epidemiologic data pointing to possible exposure to contaminated water or animals. Early diagnosis and treatment are crucial to prevent complications such as Weil's disease, which can lead to severe renal and hepatic issues.

 

Reference - Harrison 21/Leptospirosis/Chap 184

questions.text:
Which of the features given below is of a male pelvis?

 

  1. Triangular obturator foramen

  2. U-shaped pubic angle

  3. Everted ischial tuberosity

  4. Large greater sciatic notch

  5. Large acetabulum

  6. Deep preauricular sulcus
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Only 5   

 

Large acetabulum: The acetabulum in males is generally larger to support a greater range of motion and the weight of a more muscular body.

 

Other Features:

 

1. Triangular obturator foramen: Typically seen in males.

 

2. U-shaped pubic angle: This is more characteristic of the female pelvis, which has a wider pubic angle to facilitate childbirth.

 

3. Everted ischial tuberosity: This is more common in females.

 

4. Large greater sciatic notch: More pronounced in females.

 

6. Deep preauricular sulcus: More commonly seen in females.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Differences between male and female pelvis

questions.text:
Match the following: (INICET NOV 2022)

 

 

Tooth

A. Canine

B. Lateral incisor

C. First molar

D. Third molar

 

Age of eruption

1. 6-7 years

2. 8-9 years

3. 11-12 years

4. 17-25 yearss
questions.solution:
Ans. C) A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4

 

The correct option is Option C. A-3, B-2, C-1, D-4.

 

The time of emergence of secondary dentition or permanent teeth is crucial in pediatric and forensic medicine. For the given teeth:

 

  • First molar: The first molar typically erupts around 6-7 years of age.
  • Lateral incisor: Lateral incisors emerge around 7-9 years of age.
  • Canine: Canines usually emerge between 11-12 years of age.
  • Third molar: The third molars (also known as wisdom teeth) usually appear between 17-25 years of age.

 

This matches the arrangement in Option C, which makes it the correct answer.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. A-1, B-3, C-2, D-4: Incorrect. The lateral incisor is assigned to an incorrect age range, as lateral incisors erupt between 7-9 years, not 11-12 years as implied here.

 

Option B. A-3, B-4, C-1, D-2: Incorrect. The third molar has an incorrect assigned range of 8-9 years, which is too early for its eruption, typically occurring much later (17-25 years).

 

Option D. A-2, B-3, C-4, D-1: Incorrect. The sequence places the first molar too late at 17-25 years, which is actually the time for the third molar's eruption, making this option invalid.

 

Educational Objective:

 

The correct timeline of tooth eruption for different types of permanent teeth is essential for understanding developmental milestones, particularly in pediatrics and forensic medicine. Key timings include:

 

  • First molar: 6-7 years
  • Lateral incisor: 7-9 years
  • Canine: 11-12 years
  • Third molar: 17-25 years

choices.text: Increases urine output
Increases mean arterial blood pressure

questions.text: A patient of septicemia was treated with norepinephrine infusion. Which of the following best parameter is used to monitor the effect of therapy? (AIIMS Nov 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Increases mean arterial blood pressure

 

Norepinephrine/ Noradrenaline, is a vasopressor commonly used in the management of septic shock. It works primarily by stimulating α1 and α2 adrenergic receptors, leading to vasoconstriction and an increase in systemic vascular resistance. It also stimulates β1 receptors, which increases cardiac output.

 

  • Increase in Mean Arterial Blood Pressure (MAP): The primary goal of using norepinephrine in septic shock is to improve perfusion by increasing MAP. Monitoring MAP is essential because it provides a direct measure of the pressure needed to ensure adequate blood flow to organs. An increase in MAP indicates improved perfusion and is a key indicator of the efficacy of norepinephrine therapy.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Bradycardia: Bradycardia can occur as a reflex response to the increase in blood pressure caused by norepinephrine. However, it is not a primary parameter for monitoring the therapeutic effect of norepinephrine in septic shock.

 

Option B. Tachycardia: Tachycardia is not typically expected with norepinephrine therapy and can be a sign of other issues or a compensatory response. It is not a direct indicator of norepinephrine efficacy.

 

Option C. Increases urine output: While increased urine output is a good sign of improved renal perfusion and overall hemodynamic status, it is a secondary measure. The primary aim is to stabilize the patient's blood pressure, making MAP the more direct parameter to monitor.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Noradrenaline acts on the α1, α2 and β1 receptors. It leads to an increase in the SBP, a rise in DBP and therefore a rise in MAP. This helps in improving the perfusion in patients suffering from septic shock. The rise in mean arterial pressure also causes reflex bradycardia but it is not a major contributor to the treatment of septic shock

questions.text: After administering the patch test to a 10-year-old boy with a history of allergic contact dermatitis, when should you schedule his return for patch removal? (AIIMS May 2019)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 48 hours

 

The Gold standard Diagnostic test for Airborne contact dermatitis (ABCD) & Allergic Contact Dermatitis (ACD) is a patch test. 

 

Patch testing:

 

  • It is a method used to determine if a specific substance causes allergic inflammation of a patient's skin.
  • It is typically indicated for patients with suspected allergic contact dermatitis.
  • The test involves the application of various substances in small chambers or patches to the skin, usually on the back.
  • After the application of a patch test, the patches are generally removed at 48 hours (2 days), and an initial reading is taken.
  • This timeframe allows for the elicitation of a Type IV or delayed-type hypersensitivity reaction, which is the basis of allergic contact dermatitis.
  • However, readings at 48 hours may not be sufficient to detect all reactions, and thus an additional reading at 96 hours is often recommended.
  • The additional reading helps to identify late reactions, which could otherwise be missed if only the 48-hour reading is considered.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 24 hours

 

  • This timeframe is too short for most delayed-type hypersensitivity reactions to occur.
  • Removing the patches at 24 hours would likely result in missing many positive reactions.

 

Option B. 72 hours

 

  • It is not typically when the patches are first removed.
  • The patches are usually removed at 48 hours, and the skin is then inspected for any reactions.

 

Option D. 96 hours

 

  • This is a common time for a follow-up reading and not the initial removal of the patches.
  • Some protocols suggest readings at this time to ensure that late-appearing reactions are not missed.

 

The image below shows a patch test:

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

 

Ref- Rooks textbook of dermatology - 9th Edition volume I Chapter 4 page no 4.23

Fitzpatrick’s dermatology 9th edition page no 406

Online resources: https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC3900336/

questions.text: Identify the disorder with X-linked dominant inheritance: (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Rett syndrome

 

Rett syndrome is inherited in an X-linked dominant pattern.

 

Rett syndrome:

 

 

Other examples of XLD disorders include Vitamin D Independent Rickets, Aicardi Syndrome, Hypophosphatemic Rickets, Incontinentia pigmenti.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD): Duchenne muscular dystrophy (DMD) is inherited in X linked recessive pattern. It is caused by mutations in the dystrophin gene and predominantly affects boys, leading to progressive muscle weakness and wasting.

Option C. Huntington's disease: Huntington's disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern. It is characterized by progressive neurodegeneration, leading to motor dysfunction, cognitive decline, and psychiatric symptoms.           

 

Option D. Tuberous sclerosis: Tuberous sclerosis / Bournville disease is inherited in an autosomal dominant pattern, characterized by the development of benign tumors in multiple organs.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Rett syndrome is an X-linked dominant disorder most commonly seen in girls, characterized by microcephaly, regression of motor milestones, developmental delay, and stereotyped movements.

choices.text: 2 doses of vaccine on Day 0 & 3
5 doses of vaccine with Immunoglobulin

questions.text: A 5-year-old boy, previously vaccinated against rabies a year ago, was bitten by his vaccinated family pet dog on the toe, resulting in a bleeding wound. What is the most appropriate next step in the management of this child? [AIIMS NOV 2019]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) 2 doses of vaccine on Day 0 & 3

 

  • The patient should receive 2 doses of vaccine on days 0 & 3 as he has already received a prior course of post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) > 3 months ago.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • For a previously vaccinated individual bitten by a potentially rabid animal, the appropriate post-exposure prophylaxis is to administer 2 booster doses of the rabies vaccine on days 0 and 3.

choices.text: Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate

questions.text: A patient with erectile dysfunction is given sildenafil. Which of the following mediates the action of sildenafil? (INICET Nov 2022)
questions.solution:
Ans. B. cGMP

 

  • Sildenafil is a phosphodiesterase 5 inhibitor.
  • The corpus cavernosum produces nitric oxide during arousal that stimulates the formation of cGMP. cGMP causes relaxation of the smooth muscle of the corpus cavernosum and penile arteries, engorgement of the corpus cavernosum, and erection.
  • By inhibiting PDE 5, the hydrolysis if cGMP is prevented, thus leading to erection.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. cAMP: cAMP (cyclic adenosine monophosphate) is another second messenger involved in various biological processes, but it is not the primary mediator in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for erectile dysfunction.

 

Option C. Calcium: Calcium plays a critical role in muscle contraction and various cellular functions, but it is not directly involved in the mechanism of action of sildenafil for treating erectile dysfunction.

 

Option D. Phosphatidyl glycerol and inositol phosphate: These molecules are involved in different signaling pathways, such as the phosphatidylinositol pathway, but they are not relevant to the action of sildenafil.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Sildenafil, a PDE5 inhibitor, enhances and prolongs erections by preventing the breakdown of cGMP, which is the primary mediator responsible for smooth muscle relaxation and increased blood flow in the corpus cavernosum of the penis during arousal.

questions.text: HPV Nonavalent vaccine is active against which of the following serotypes? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58

 

Explanation:

 

HPV Vaccines available are:

 

  1. Cervarix (Bivalent): 16, 18
  2. Gardasil (Quadrivalent): 6, 11, 16, 18
  3. Nonavalent: (Gardasil 9 or HPV9): 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.
  4. Cervavac (India’s indigenous HPV vaccine): Quadrivalent: 6, 11, 16, 18

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Gardasil 9 is a nonavalent HPV vaccine effective against 9 serotypes of the virus
  • These include: 6, 11, 16, 18, 31, 33, 45, 52, 58.

 

Ref: https://www.merckvaccines.com/gardasil9/

questions.text:
Regarding urinary tract infection (UTI) in children, which of the following is true? (INICET NOV 2022)

 

  1. Most common cause of UTI is Streptococcus pneumoniae.
  2. Bowel, bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  3. Cotrimoxazole is not given.
  4. Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is done in children with recurrence of UTI.
questions.solution:
Ans. B) 2, 4

 

The true statements regarding UTI in children are:

 

  • Bowel and bladder dysfunction increases the risk of recurrence.
  • Micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) is performed in children with recurrent UTIs.

 

The most common cause of UTI in children is Escherichia coli (E. coli), not Streptococcus pneumoniae (hence, statement 1 is incorrect). Bowel and bladder dysfunction can lead to incomplete emptying of the bladder, increasing the risk of bacterial infections and subsequent UTI recurrence.

 

Cotrimoxazole is used as both treatment and prophylaxis for UTI in children, particularly to prevent recurrent infections (making statement 3 incorrect).

 

MCU is performed in cases of recurrent UTI to evaluate structural abnormalities, such as vesicoureteral reflux (VUR), which can contribute to infection risk.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 1, 3, 4: This is incorrect as Streptococcus pneumoniae is not the most common cause of UTI in children, and cotrimoxazole is indeed used for UTI treatment and prevention.

 

Option C. 2, 3, 4: This option is partially correct, but cotrimoxazole is used for UTI treatment, so statement 3 is incorrect.

 

Option D. 1, 4: Incorrect because Streptococcus pneumoniae is not the most common cause of UTI in children.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In pediatric patients, Escherichia coli is the most common pathogen causing UTIs. Risk factors for recurrent UTIs include bladder and bowel dysfunction. Evaluation of recurrent UTIs typically involves a micturating cysto-urethrogram (MCU) to assess for structural issues like vesicoureteral reflux (VUR). Cotrimoxazole is commonly used for treatment and as prophylaxis to prevent recurrent infections.

questions.text: The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a: (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. D. Fibrous joint

 

Explanation:

 

The middle radioulnar joint is an example of a fibrous joint (syndesmosis).

 

Fibrous joints are joints where bones are connected by fibrous tissue, such as ligaments or sutures.

 

Examples of fibrous joints include the sutures of the skull and the syndesmosis between the radius and ulna at the distal radioulnar joint.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Plane synovial: Plane synovial joints are also known as gliding joints. They allow for limited gliding or sliding movements between flat articular surfaces. Examples of plane synovial joints include the intercarpal joints of the wrist.

 

Option B. Primary cartilaginous: Primary cartilaginous joints, also called synchondroses, are joints where bones are connected by hyaline cartilage. An example of a primary cartilaginous joint is the epiphyseal plate in growing long bones.

 

Option C. Secondary cartilaginous: Secondary cartilaginous joints, or symphyses, are joints where bones are connected by fibrocartilage. Examples include the intervertebral discs and the pubic symphysis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Three joints connect the radius and ulna to one another:

 

  • Proximal (superior) radioulnar joint
  • Middle radioulnar joint
  • Distal (inferior) radioulnar joint

 

Proximal and distal radioulnar joints are uniaxial pivot joints (synovial) and are involved in pronation and supination movements of the forearm.

 

The middle radioulnar joint is a fibrous joint (syndesmosis). The radius and ulna, in the middle, are connected by two syndesmoses namely:

 

  1. The oblique cord - extends distally from the radial tuberosity to the radius from the lateral side of the ulnar tuberosity.
  2. Interosseous membrane - a broad, thin collagenous structure, which runs perpendicular to the oblique cord. It extends distomedially between the interosseous borders of the radius and ulna.

questions.text: Identify the sign? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Babinski sign


The Babinski sign is a reflex response where the big toe extends upward and the other toes fan out upon stimulation of the sole. This indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

 

Other Options:
 

Option B. Ankle jerk: Reflex action at the ankle joint.
 

Option C. Jendrassik: Maneuver to enhance reflexes.
 

Option D. Normal plantar response: Flexion of all toes.

 

Educational Objective:

 

A positive Babinski sign indicates an upper motor neuron lesion.

questions.text: A patient is not able to see the lateral fields. He was having a mild headache for a few weeks and now presented to the clinic. Visual field examination shows the following finding. What is the probable site of the lesion based on the image displayed?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Optic chiasma

 

The visual field defect in the image is indicative of bitemporal hemianopia, so the probable site of the lesion is the optic chiasma.

 

The most common cause of this is pituitary gland tumours.

 

Other causes include suprasellar aneurysms, chronic arachnoiditis, suprasellar tumours like craniopharyngioma and suprasellar meningioma.

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Occipital lobe: Lesions here typically cause congruent homonymous hemianopia, where the same visual field is lost in both eyes, not bitemporal defects.

 

Option C. Optic tract: Lesions in the optic tract cause homonymous hemianopia, affecting the same side of the visual field in both eyes.

 

Option D. Optic radiation: Lesions here also cause homonymous hemianopia, but depending on the location, they might lead to variations like a superior or inferior quadrantanopia.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Visual field defects:

questions.text:
Arrange the following in the sequence of auditory pathway: (INICET Nov 2020)

 

  1. Cochlear nucleus
  2. Spiral ganglion
  3. Superior olivary nucleus
  4. Inferior colliculus
  5. Medial geniculate body
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 2 - 1 - 3 - 4 - 5

 

The auditory pathway is the sequence of neural structures that sound information travels through from the ear to the brain for processing. The correct sequence from the initial sensory input at the ear to the higher centers of the brain is as follows:

 

2. Spiral ganglion : Contains the cell bodies of the auditory nerve fibers. These neurons receive mechanical sound vibrations converted into electrical signals by the hair cells of the cochlea.

 

1. Cochlear nucleus : The first brainstem nucleus where auditory nerve fibers synapse. This nucleus begins the central processing of auditory information.

 

3. Superior olivary nucleus : Receives inputs from both cochlear nuclei and is involved in binaural cues for sound localization.

 

4. Inferior colliculus : A midbrain nucleus that acts as a major relay and integration point for auditory information.

 

5. Medial geniculate body : Part of the thalamus that acts as the final relay station for auditory information being sent to the auditory cortex in the brain.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The correct sequence of structures involved in the auditory pathway from the periphery to the center is (E COLI MA). 
    1. Eighth (Vestibulocochlear) nerve
    2. Cochlear Nucleus
    3. Superior Olivary nucleus
    4. Lateral lemniscus
    5. Inferior colliculus
    6. Medial geniculate body
    7. Auditory cortex
  • The spiral ganglion situated in Rosenthal's canal contains bipolar cells. The dendrites of these bipolar cells join to form the cochlear branch of the vestibulocochlear nerve which ends in the cochlear nuclei.

questions.text: During the separation of the spleen from the stomach while performing splenectomy, bleeding is likely to occur from which source? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Short gastric artery


During splenectomy, when separating the spleen from the stomach near the fundus, the short gastric vessels are most likely to bleed. These vessels are branches of the splenic artery that supply the fundus of the stomach. The short gastric vessels run in the gastrosplenic ligament connecting the fundus of the stomach to the splenic hilum. These vessels must be divided during splenectomy and can be a source of bleeding during or after the procedure.

 

 

Other Options: 


Option B. Left gastroepiploic artery: Incorrect. Left gastroepiploic artery runs along the greater curvature of the stomach and is not typically encountered during the fundal dissection of splenectomy.

 

Option C. Right gastroepiploic artery: Incorrect. Right gastroepiploic artery is on the right side of the greater curvature and is not involved in splenic dissection.

 

Option D. Splenic artery: Incorrect. The main splenic artery runs at a lower level on the superior border of the pancreas and is not encountered during the fundal dissection. It would only be encountered during posterior dissection or pancreatic surgery.

 

Educational Objective:


Short gastric vessels running in the gastrosplenic ligament between the splenic hilum and gastric fundus are the most likely source of bleeding during splenic dissection from stomach during splenectomy.

questions.text: Which of the following is normally seen in lumbar spine? (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.solution:
Ans. C. Lordosis

 

Explanation:

 

Lordosis refers to the inward (anterior) curvature of the spine. It's the normal anatomical curvature seen in the lumbar (lower back) and cervical (neck) regions. In the lumbar region, lordosis allows for an upright posture and helps to evenly distribute the body's weight and the forces exerted on the spine. While a certain degree of lumbar lordosis is normal and healthy, excessive lordosis (often called "swayback") can lead to pain and other issues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Scoliosis: Scoliosis refers to a lateral (side-to-side) curvature of the spine. While any part of the spine can be affected, scoliosis most commonly develops in the thoracic (upper/mid back) and/or lumbar (lower back) regions. It's important to note that while scoliosis can affect the lumbar spine, it is not the normal anatomical curvature for that region. Instead, it's a pathological condition which can be idiopathic (most common, especially in adolescents), congenital, or secondary to other conditions.

 

Option B. Kyphosis: Kyphosis describes a forward (anterior) rounding or curvature of the spine, producing a "hunchback" appearance. The normal anatomical region that displays kyphosis is the thoracic spine (upper/mid back). When present in the lumbar spine, it is considered pathological and is usually secondary to conditions like osteoporosis (which causes compression fractures), degenerative diseases, or other spine disorders.

 

Option D. Recurvatum: Recurvatum typically refers to a backward bending or hyperextension of a joint. While this term can be applied to various joints in the body, it's most commonly associated with the knee joint, where the knee bends backward excessively. It doesn't directly pertain to the natural anatomical curvatures of the spine.

 

Educational Objective:

 

In adults,

 

  • The cervical curve is a lordosis (convex forwards),
  • The thoracic curve is a kyphosis (convex dorsally),
  • The lumbar curve is also a lordosis,
  • The pelvic curve is concave anteroinferiorly.

questions.text: A confirmed case of viral hemorrhagic fever was identified in a hospital in India, with transmission occurring person-to-person. The disease is tick-borne and caused by a Nairovirus species. Which of the following viral hemorrhagic fevers was confirmed in this case?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever

 

Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a severe viral hemorrhagic fever caused by the Nairovirus species. It is zoonotic in origin, with ticks serving as vectors. The disease can be transmitted to humans through tick bites or via person-to-person transmission in healthcare settings, particularly during outbreaks. Cases have been reported in several regions, including India.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Ebola: Ebola is another viral hemorrhagic fever, but it is caused by a Filovirus, not a Nairovirus, and is primarily found in sub-Saharan Africa.

 

Option B. Yellow fever: Yellow fever is transmitted by Aedes mosquitoes and caused by a Flavivirus. It is endemic to regions of Africa and South America, but not typically seen in India.

 

Option D. Marburg: Marburg virus is also a Filovirus, similar to Ebola, and is primarily found in Africa.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • Crimean-Congo hemorrhagic fever (CCHF) is a tick-borne viral hemorrhagic fever caused by Nairovirus. It has been reported in India and can spread via person-to-person transmission, particularly in healthcare settings.

questions.text: Identify the type of hypoxia according to given graph: (Brown graph is normal) (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. D) Anemic hypoxia

 

The given graph illustrates a 50% reduction in the oxygen saturation of hemoglobin, even though the partial pressure of oxygen (PO2) stays within the expected range. This state is termed anemic hypoxia.

 

Anemic hypoxia occurs when there is a reduction in the oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood, usually due to a lower amount of hemoglobin, as seen in anemia. Despite normal levels of PO2, the overall oxygen content in the blood is diminished, leading to insufficient oxygen delivery to tissues.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Stagnant hypoxia: This occurs when oxygen deficiency is due to poor blood circulation, not a reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of the blood. It is caused by issues like arterial obstruction or ischemia. The graph for stagnant hypoxia would show normal oxygen content in arterial blood but lower content in venous blood due to poor perfusion.

 

Option B. Histotoxic hypoxia: In this type, the cells are unable to utilize oxygen effectively, even though it is adequately supplied by the blood. This condition is typically caused by toxins like cyanide that impair cellular respiration. The graph for histotoxic hypoxia would show normal oxygen content in both arterial and venous blood since the issue is within the cells' ability to use oxygen, not the blood's ability to transport it.

 

Option C. Hypoxic hypoxia: This occurs when there is a generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues due to low oxygen in the blood, often seen at high altitudes or in conditions like COPD. The graph would show reduced PO2 along with decreased oxygen content in both arterial and venous blood.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  1. Stagnant hypoxia: Oxygen deficiency due to poor blood circulation.
  2. Histotoxic hypoxia: Cells unable to utilize oxygen despite its availability.
  3. Hypoxic hypoxia: Generalized lack of oxygen in the body's tissues.
  4. Anemic hypoxia: Reduced oxygen-carrying capacity of blood due to low hemoglobin.

choices.text: Decreases risk of Colon cancer
Decreased risk of breast cancer
Decreased risk of endometrial cancer
Increases risk of osteoporosis

questions.text: Which of the following is a true association related to HRT (Hormone replacement therapy) among the options provided? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Decreases risk of Colon cancer

 

Explanation:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) has been associated with a decreased risk of colon cancer. Studies have shown that estrogen in HRT may have a protective effect against the development of colon cancer. This effect is believed to be related to estrogen’s impact on gastrointestinal mucosal growth and repair.

 

Other options:

 

Option B. Decreased risk of breast cancer: This option is incorrect. HRT, particularly with estrogen and progestin, is associated with an increased risk of breast cancer. Long-term use of combined HRT has been shown to elevate the risk of breast cancer in several studies.

 

Option C. Decreased risk of endometrial cancer: This option is incorrect. Unopposed estrogen (estrogen alone without progestin) increases the risk of endometrial cancer. To mitigate this risk, progestin is often added to HRT in women with an intact uterus.

 

Option D. Increases risk of osteoporosis: This option is incorrect. HRT is actually used prophylactically to reduce the risk of osteoporosis. Estrogen helps maintain bone density and prevent bone loss, which is beneficial in managing osteoporosis.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hormone Replacement Therapy (HRT) decreases the risk of colon cancer.

questions.text: A 75-year-old male after a fall in bathroom had hip fracture as seen in the pelvic X-ray below. What will be the position of the left lower limb?(AIIMS MAY 2017)
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Shortened and externally rotated

 

HIP FRACTURE

 

  • The given image in the question shows a displaced femoral neck fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are a specific type of intracapsular hip fracture.
  • Femoral neck fractures are associated with low energy falls in the elderly.
  • In younger patients, the cause is usually secondary to high-energy trauma such as fall from a substantial height or motor vehicle accidents. 
  • Risk factors for femoral neck fractures include female gender, decreased mobility, and low bone density.
  • 70% of all hip fractures occur in women. 
  • Symptoms include pain in the groin or pain referred along the medial side of the thigh and knee in an impacted fracture.
  • In a displaced fracture, there will be pain in the entire hip. 
  • In an impacted fracture, there is no obvious clinical deformity on examination. There is mild discomfort in the active/passive hip range of motion, and pain with percussion over the greater trochanter.
  • In displaced fractures, the leg appears in external rotation and abduction deformity with shortening of the limb.

 

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The given image shows a displaced femoral neck fracture in the elderly patient.
  • Following the fracture, the limb appears shortened with external rotation and abduction deformity at the hip.

choices.text: 200 mL/hour

questions.text: What is the normal insensible water loss?
questions.solution:
Ans. C) 50 mL/hour

 

The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour.

 

In human beings, there is a loss of water through vaporization from the respiratory tract (300–400 mL) and diffusion from the skin (300–400 mL). This is called insensible water loss. It is about 50 mL/hour. This insensible water loss via the skin is independent of sweating and occurs in people without sweat glands as well.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. 100 mL/hour: 100 mL/hour is incorrect. The normal insensible water loss is 50 mL/hour, not 100 mL/hour.

 

Option B. 150 mL/hour: 150 mL/hour is incorrect. Insensible water loss is less, typically around 50 mL/hour.

 

Option D. 200 mL/hour: 200 mL/hour is incorrect. This value is too high for normal insensible water loss.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Insensible water loss is the loss of water through vaporization from the respiratory tract and diffusion from the skin, which accounts for approximately 50 mL/hour in humans.

questions.text: A patient came with hypoxemia and a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient. What can be the cause? (INICET NOV 2021)
questions.solution:
Ans. C) Hypoventilation

 

Hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial (A-a) oxygen gradient typically points to specific causes where the alveolar oxygen (PAO2) and arterial oxygen (PaO2) levels remain proportionate. In this scenario, the primary causes are hypoventilation and situations involving low inspired oxygen tension (low FiO2).

 

Hypoventilation: This condition leads to hypoxemia due to inadequate ventilation. When ventilation is insufficient, the amount of oxygen entering the alveoli drops, leading to a corresponding decrease in the amount of oxygen diffusing into the blood, resulting in hypoxemia. However, because the underlying issue is with ventilation and not with oxygen diffusion or blood flow, the A-a gradient remains normal.

 

Low FiO2 or Low Barometric Pressure: This can occur in scenarios such as high altitude where the barometric pressure is low, leading to reduced oxygen availability in the air. However, these situations were not explicitly listed among the answer choices.

 

According to the reference paragraph, other conditions like ventilation/perfusion (V/Q) mismatch, diffusion limitation, and alveolar membrane damage, cause an increased A-a gradient due to impaired oxygen transfer across the alveolar membrane or mismatched ventilation and perfusion in the lungs.

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Right to left shunt: This condition causes hypoxemia due to blood bypassing the lungs and not getting oxygenated. It leads to an increased A-a gradient because the oxygen content of the arterial blood is significantly lower compared to the alveolar oxygen level.

 

Option B. Ventilation/Perfusion mismatch: This condition results from areas of the lung receiving oxygen but not perfused with blood or areas perfused with blood but not receiving oxygen. It causes an increased A-a gradient due to ineffective oxygen transfer to the blood.

 

Option D. Alveolar membrane damage: This results in impaired oxygen diffusion across the alveolar-capillary membrane, leading to an increased A-a gradient as oxygen transfer from alveoli to blood is hindered.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Hypoventilation is a primary cause of hypoxemia with a normal alveolar-arterial oxygen gradient.

questions.text: A 30-year-old resident physician was exposed to HIV through a needlestick injury and has come to the emergency department seeking help. You decide to start her on post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP). Which of the following drug combinations is most recommended for PEP in this scenario? [AIIMS MAY 2020]
questions.solution:
Ans. (b) Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir for 4 weeks 

 

  • Post-exposure prophylaxis (PEP) is an emergency treatment for HIV exposure, typically recommended to be started as soon as possible after exposure, ideally within 2 hours and no later than 72 hours.
  • The choice of antiretroviral therapy for PEP should be guided by current recommendations that prioritize effectiveness and tolerability.
  • Lamivudine + Tenofovir + Dolutegravir (Option B): This combination is currently recommended for PEP due to its high efficacy, good tolerability, and strong safety profile. Tenofovir and Lamivudine provide a potent backbone of nucleoside reverse transcriptase inhibitors (NRTIs), while Dolutegravir acts as an integrase strand transfer inhibitor (INSTI), which has a rapid onset of action and is well-tolerated.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Post Exposure Prophylaxis HIV

 

Preferably within 24 hours. Maximum within 72 hours.

 

Duration of prophylaxis is 28 days

questions.text: Which action will be impacted in PIN Palsy? (INICET NOV 2024)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) Extension of fingers

 

  • PIN palsy can occur from repetitive pronation-supination movements, fracture/dislocation (e.g., monteggia fracture, radial head fracture, etc.), ganglion, rheumatoid synovitis of radiocapitellar joint.
  • PIN is a branch of the radial nerve that provides motor innervation to the extensor compartment of the forearm. 
  • Course:
    • Passes between the two heads of origin of the supinator muscle 
    • Direct contact with the radial neck 
    • Passes over abductor pollicis longus muscle origin to reach interosseous membrane
    • Transverses along the posterior interosseous membrane
  • Innervation:
    • Common extensors: ECRB, Extensor digitorum communis, Extensor digiti minimi, Extensor carpi ulnaris 
    • Deep extensors: Supinator, Abductor pollicis longus, Extensor pollicus brevis, Extensor pollicus longus 
  • The symptoms of PIN palsy are often insidious in onset, usually goes undiagnosed.
  • The patient complaints of pain in the forearm and wrist, and weakness of finger, wrist and thumb movements 
  • On examination, there is forearm extensor compartment muscle atrophy, weakness of finger metacarpal extension, wrist extension, and an inability to extend wrist in ulnar deviation. 

 

Other Options:

 

Option A. Supination of forearm: This movement is facilitated by the supinator, biceps brachii and brachioradialis muscles. The supinator muscle is supplied by the PIN, but it has some innervation from the radial nerve before the PIN branches off, so supination is usually not completely lost. The bicep brachii is supplied by the musculocutaneous nerve while the brachioradialis is supplied by the radial nerve.

 

Option C. Extension of elbow: The primary elbow extensor muscles are triceps brachii and anconeus. It is supplied by the radial nerve, thus it remains unaffected in PIN palsy. 

 

Option D. Wrist drop: Wrist drop is a disorder caused by radial nerve palsy. Because of the radial nerve's innervation of the extensor muscles of the wrist and digits, those whose radial nerve function has been compromised cannot actively extend them. As such, the hand hangs flaccidly in a position of flexion when the patient attempts to bring the arm to a horizontal position.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • PIN palsy is a neuropathic compression of the posterior interosseous nerve where it passes through the radial tunnel.
  • This may result in paresis or paralysis of the digital and thumb extensor muscles, resulting in an inability to extend the thumb and fingers at their MCP joints.
  • Wrist extension is preserved due to the action of the extensor carpi radialis longus innervated by the radial nerve.

questions.text: What does the provided formula correspond to? [INICET MAY 2023]
questions.solution:
Ans. (a) Standard deviation

 

  • Standard deviation is the Root of Mean od Squares of Deviations

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Variance: Variance = (Standard deviation)2

 

Option C. Mean: Mean is obtained as sum of all values divided by the number of values in the distribution. It is not affected by extreme values.

 

Option D. Median: Median is the middle most value in a distribution arranged in an ascending or descending order of values.

 

Educational Objective:

 

  • The standard deviation measures the dispersion of a data set around its mean.

questions.text: Which of the following fibres reach the Purkinje cell directly?
questions.solution:
Ans. A) Inferior olivary nucleus

 

The fibres of inferior olivary nucleus (climbing fibres) reach the purkinje cell directly.

 

The inferior olivary nucleus is a key part of the cerebellar circuitry and is responsible for providing input to the Purkinje cells via the climbing fibers. These fibers make direct synaptic connections with Purkinje cells and are involved in the modulation of motor learning, control, and coordination. The inferior olivary nucleus receives a wide range of inputs from other areas of the brain, including the spinal cord and sensory systems, and is thought to play an important role in the integration of sensory and motor information during movement.

 

Excitatory and inhibitory fibres –

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B. Raphe nucleus: Primarily associated with serotonin production, influencing many brain functions including mood and sleep, but does not directly connect to Purkinje cells.

 

Option C. Vestibular nucleus: Sends information to the cerebellum about head position and movement via mossy fibers, not directly to Purkinje cells.

 

Option D. Locus coeruleus: Provides widespread noradrenergic projections that influence arousal and attentiveness, not directly targeting Purkinje cells.

 

Educational Objective:

 

Climbing fibers from the inferior olivary nucleus directly synapse onto Purkinje cells in the cerebellum, playing a pivotal role in motor control and learning processes.

questions.text: Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is given by? (INICET Nov 2020)
questions.solution:
Ans. B) A

 

Among the shown options, Gibbs free energy change of an enzyme-catalysed reaction is shown by A.

 

Formation of a product requires the breaking of substrate bonds and conformational change forming a highly unstable transitional state intermediate, it requires energy and this is called Gibbs free energy of activation. In an enzyme-catalysed reaction, this energy barrier is reduced by forming a relatively stable intermediate-enzyme complex. The enzyme provides attachment sites for the substrate and speeds up the rate of reaction. It doesn't change the Gibbs energy of either the substrate or the product. Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalysed reaction (with no intermediate state) is shown in the image given below.

 

 

Other Options:

 

Option B: All the reactions have a transition state, but not all reactions have an intermediate state. There are 2 reasons as to why option B

 

  1. ﻿﻿﻿Transition state intermediate usually has higher energy compared to the substrate or product. Very unusually a dip might be seen like this when the enzyme-intermediate complex is more stable than the product, and the product is not formed.
  2. ﻿﻿﻿Every intermediate state is again, always followed by another transition state. Therefore, every reaction, if it has an intermediate state, needs to have two transition states as shown in the image given below. We don't have 2 such transition states in curve B in the question, which makes it an incorrect answer.

 

 

Option C: Free energy change cannot be a straight line. It has to pass through a high energy intermediate state

 

Option D: Transition energy intermediate never has lower energy compared to the product

 

Educational Objective:

 

The Gibbs free energy curve of an enzyme-catalyzed reaction is best represented by Curve A, which shows the formation of a transition state and the reduction in activation energy, leading to the production of the final product.
